prompt_init: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
initial_story:
A US Army soldier stationed in South Korea has been detained in Russia, the US military says.

The Russian foreign ministry said the charges were not related to "politics or espionage", but to a "purely domestic crime".

The 34-year-old was not on official travel when he was held on 2 May in the city of Vladivostok, in Russia's Far East.

Sgt Black had been in the process of changing duty stations from South Korea to Fort Cavazos in the US state of Texas, according to a statement from the US Army.

But instead of returning to the US, he travelled through China to Vladivostok for personal reasons, US Army spokeswoman Cynthia Smith said in a statement.

According to Russian media, he was visiting a woman with whom he had a romantic relationship.

The soldier's mother, Melody Jones, confirmed to CBS that he was in Russia visiting his girlfriend.

"Please do not torture him [or] hurt him," Melody Jones said when asked about her message to the Russians.

Sgt Black enlisted as an infantryman in 2008 and was deployed to Iraq in 2009 and Afghanistan in 2013. He was most recently assigned to the Eighth Army, US Forces Korea at Camp Humphreys in South Korea.

He did not request official clearance and the defence department did not authorise his travel to China or Russia, the US Army said. There is no evidence he intended to remain in Russia.

The Russian interior ministry informed the US embassy in Moscow on 3 May that Sgt Black had been arrested a day earlier for theft of personal property.

He is being held at a pre-trial detention facility until his next hearing.

"The Army notified his family and the US Department of State is providing appropriate consular support to the Soldier in Russia," the US Army said in a statement on Monday.

National Security Council spokesman John Kirby told reporters the US is "aware of this case and other matters related to Russia".

At the White House briefing on Monday, Mr Kirby said he could not provide more details.

Russia is holding two other Americans. Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich has been detained since March 2023 on espionage charges.

Former US Marine Paul Whelan was accused of spying and sentenced to 16 years in prison in 2020.

Both men maintain their innocence, and the US government says the charges against them are baseless.
stories:
A 34-year-old US Army sergeant, stationed in South Korea, has been taken into custody in Russia, according to the US military. 

The Russian foreign ministry claims the charges against him are unrelated to political or espionage activities, but rather a common criminal offense. 

The soldier, who was not on official duty, was detained on May 2 in Vladivostok, Russia's Far East region. 

He was in the process of being transferred from South Korea to Fort Cavazos in Texas, but instead, he traveled to Vladivostok, via China, for personal reasons. 

Russian media reports suggest he was visiting a romantic partner, which his mother, Melody Jones, confirmed to CBS News. 

Jones pleaded with the Russian authorities not to harm her son. 

Sgt Black, who enlisted in 2008, had previously been deployed to Iraq and Afghanistan, and was most recently assigned to the Eighth Army in South Korea. 

He did not obtain official clearance for his trip to China and Russia, and there is no indication he intended to remain in Russia. 

The Russian interior ministry notified the US embassy in Moscow that Sgt Black had been arrested for theft, and he is currently being held at a pre-trial detention facility. 

The US Army has notified his family and is providing consular support through the US Department of State. 

The National Security Council is aware of the case, but could not provide further details. 

Russia is also holding two other Americans, including Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich, who has been detained since March on espionage charges, and former US Marine Paul Whelan, who was sentenced to 16 years in prison in 2020 on spying charges. Both men deny the allegations and the US government considers the charges to be baseless.

A 34-year-old US Army sergeant, based in South Korea, has been arrested in Russia, the US military has confirmed. 

The Russian foreign ministry asserts that the sergeant is facing a common criminal charge, unrelated to political or espionage activities. 

The soldier, who was not on duty at the time, was detained on May 2 in Vladivostok, a city in Russia's Far East. 

He was in the process of being relocated from South Korea to a base in Texas, but instead, he traveled to Vladivostok via China for personal reasons. 

According to Russian media, the sergeant was visiting a romantic partner, which his mother has confirmed. 

His mother has appealed to the Russian authorities to ensure her son's safety. 

The sergeant, who enlisted in 2008, has previously served in Iraq and Afghanistan and was most recently stationed with the Eighth Army in South Korea. 

He did not obtain official permission for his trip to China and Russia, and there is no indication that he intended to stay in Russia. 

The Russian interior ministry informed the US embassy in Moscow that the sergeant had been arrested on suspicion of theft, and he is currently being held in a pre-trial detention center. 

The US Army has notified his family and is providing support through the US Department of State. 

The National Security Council is aware of the case, but cannot provide further details at this time. 

Russia is also holding two other Americans, including a Wall Street Journal reporter who has been detained on espionage charges since March, and a former US Marine who was sentenced to 16 years in prison in 2020 on spying charges. Both men deny the allegations, and the US government considers the charges to be unfounded.

A 34-year-old US Army sergeant, stationed in South Korea, was arrested in Russia, according to the US military. The Russian foreign ministry claims the sergeant is facing a routine criminal charge, unrelated to political or espionage activities. The sergeant, who was not on official duty at the time, was detained on May 2 in Vladivostok, Russia, after traveling there via China for personal reasons while being relocated to a base in Texas. Russian media reports he was visiting a romantic partner, which his mother has confirmed. His mother has appealed to Russian authorities to ensure her son's safety. The sergeant, who has served in Iraq and Afghanistan, did not obtain official permission for his trip and is currently being held in a pre-trial detention center on suspicion of theft. The US Army has notified his family and is providing support through the US Department of State, while the National Security Council is aware of the case but cannot provide further details. This incident comes as Russia is also holding two other Americans, including a Wall Street Journal reporter and a former US Marine, who deny espionage charges and are considered by the US government to be unfounded.

The sergeant was arrested on May 2 in Vladivostok, Russia, after entering the country without proper documentation, following a visit to his partner in China, where he was en route to a new assignment in Texas. His mother has confirmed these details and is urging Russian officials to ensure her son's safety and well-being. As a veteran of the conflicts in Iraq and Afghanistan, the sergeant is being held in a pre-trial facility on suspicion of theft. The US Army has informed his family and is providing support through the US Department of State, while the National Security Council is aware of the case, although it cannot provide further information at this time. This incident coincides with Russia's detention of two other Americans, including a Wall Street Journal journalist and a former US Marine, who deny allegations of spying that the US government considers unfounded.
